Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Situation2: They encounter a customer trying to return an item without a receipt and need to apply the store’s return policy.
Story:
I stood behind the register, my hands trembling slightly as I scanned the next item. The line was long, and my manager had already reminded me twice today to stick to the return policy—no exceptions, no matter how sympathetic the customer. As I looked up, my boyfriend stepped forward, holding a blender we’d bought together last month. He looked tired, his eyes searching mine for understanding. “I know I lost the receipt, but can you just help me out this once?” he whispered, glancing nervously at the people behind him.

My mind raced. We’d argued all week about money, about how we needed to save, about how I never seemed to take his side. He expected me to be supportive, to help him out, to show I cared. But the store’s policy was clear, and my job depended on following it. I could feel the weight of both roles pressing down on me—his girlfriend, expected to resolve our conflict and show loyalty; the cashier, expected to enforce the rules without exception. My heart pounded as I tried to steady my voice, caught between the demands of love and responsibility, not knowing which part of me would win.
